ygData.subject: New Journal Article Extensively Analyzes Novelty Search
ygData.msgSnippet: Joel Lehman and I are pleased to announce our new article, Abandoning Objectives: Evolution Through the Search for Novelty Alone, which is accepted to appear

Subject: New Journal Article Extensively Analyzes Novelty Search
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=CRK6pSu5zpSYXTz7qYBRMhrRTjs1u1DOgIjXXyVdZOJGY7rWZFu9

Joel Lehman and I are pleased to announce our new article, "Abandoning Obje=
ctives: Evolution Through the Search for Novelty Alone," which is accepted =
to appear in Evolutionary Computation journal.  A manuscript version is now=
 available at:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2010/lehman.ecj10.html=


Direct link: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/lehman_ecj10.pdf

This articl=
e examines the properties of novelty search in significantly more depth and=
 in a wider variety of domains than in the past.  In one new set of studies=
, novelty search is tested in the maze task with behavioral characterizatio=
ns of varying dimensionality (up to 400-dimensional), and separately with v=
arious forms of finite archive sizes.  The main result is that the dimensio=
nality of the behavior characterization is not the instrumental factor in t=
he success of novelty search and nor is novelty search hampered in general =
by limiting its archive.

The second major study is in a biped walking task=
.  Many have asked whether novelty search can work in less contrived domain=
s than the now-familiar maze domain of our 2008 conference paper.  To answe=
r this question, this new paper shows novelty search outperforming fitness-=
based search in this challenging domain.  The result that a simulated biped=
 learns to balance and walk without walking set as an objective further hig=
hlights the intriguing implications of the approach.  A video of the best b=
ipeds evolved through novelty and fitness is at:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/n=
oveltysearch/

While you may already be familiar with some of the other exp=
eriments in the paper, I believe it is still worth the time to read through=
 all of it because it provides significantly broader perspective and discus=
sion than prior work, and we hope it will become the canonical reference on=
 the technique going forward.

ken
